report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
chapter_title: Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: access_timeMay 19, 2022 person_outlineAdrian Perez share

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
chapter_title: Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Phishing website links are commonly delivered via email to their respective targets. Once clicked, these websites often show a single webpage that outright asks for sensitive information like account login credentials, credit card details, and other personally identifiable information (PII).

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
chapter_title: Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Recently, we have encountered an interesting phishing website containing an interactive component in it: a chatbot. Unlike a lot of phishing websites, this one establishes a conversation first, and bit-by-bit guides the victim to the actual phishing pages.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
chapter_title: Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Although the phishing method is quite unique, it still uses email as the delivery channel. A deeper inspection of the email header shows that the From header is missing the email address component, which is a red flag already.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
chapter_title: Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Figure 1. Phishing email with spoofed From header (DHLexpress).

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
chapter_title: Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Figure 2. The spoofed "From" header does not have an email component.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
chapter_title: Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Clicking the Please follow our instructions will open a browser and direct the recipient to a downloadable PDF file. There are two ways that this file will redirect the recipient to the actual phishing site. The first is through the Fix delivery button, and the second one is by copying an alternative URL from the file.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
chapter_title: Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Figure 3. Downloadable PDF file carrying the DHL brand that contains the link to the phishing site.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
chapter_title: Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Either of the two methods will redirect the user to the same website, and this is where the actual phishing starts.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: The first stop is the chatbot-like page that tries to engage and establish trust with the victim. We say chatbot-like because it is not an actual chatbot. The application already has predefined responses based on the limited options given.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Figure 4. The portion of the JavaScript containing the predefined responses of the "chatbot".

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: The first part of the engagement simply confirms the tracking number of the supposedly ordered item.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Figure 5. Chatbot-like page confirming the order tracking number.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: By clicking the yes option, the program will try to engage at a higher level with the victim by showing the picture of the item and asking for the preferred delivery address (i.e., home or office address).

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Figure 6. The chatbot giving more details and instructions to the recipient.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: To gain even more confidence and trust from the target, a CAPTCHA is presented right after the victim clicks the Schedule delivery button. However, something is odd here nothing else is clickable except for the confirm and close button.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Figure 7. Fake CAPTCHA requiring the victim to type the exact numbers presented.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: By checking the page source, it can be confirmed that the CAPTCHA is nothing more than an embedded JPEG image file.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Figure 8. The CAPTCHA is simply an image embedded in the HTML.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: By clicking Confirm, the victim will now be redirected to another page where the chatbot asks for login credentials (i.e., email address and password) as well as the delivery address.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Figure 9. The "chatbot" asking for the victim's email, password, and delivery address.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: At this point you might think that the perpetrators have taken what they want, but you would be wrong. The phishing does not stop on this page. Clicking the Schedule Delivery and Pay button will redirect the victim again to another phishing page. This time, trying to steal credit card information.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Figure 10. Credit card details harvester.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: The credit card page has some input validation methods. One is card number validation, wherein it tries to not only check the validity of the card number but also determine the type of card the victim has inputed.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Once the victim fills out the form,clicking the PAY NOW button will redirect the victim to a loading page, which after a few seconds will then redirect to an OTP (One-Time Password) page. The OTP is an automatically generates characters (numeric or alphanumeric) which are usually sent to the users registered mobile number. This serves as another layer of user authentication for a single transaction or session.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Figure 11. The program asking for OTP that was sent to the victim's phone number.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: The fact that the web page asks for OTP is quite surprising because the previous pages did not ask for any mobile number information. Putting in random characters will just redirect you to the same page stating that the security code is no longer valid. On the fifth try, however, the page redirects to another page saying that the submission was successfully received. This marks the end of the perpetrators phishing chain.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Figure 12. A submission success status after several OTP attempts.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Summary of the Phishing Link Chain:

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: It is worth noting that the URLs start with dhi, a misspelled version of the brand name dhl or DHL, which is clearly a spoofing technique.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: The sample of this phishing email was detected by Trustwave Mailmarshal last March 25, 2022. As of this writing, the actual phishing application is still active, but now using a newly registered domain.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: In general, using chatbots adds an interactive component to a website. This often results in a higher conversion rate because it makes the site more interesting and engaging for the users. This is what the perpetrators of this phishing campaign are trying to capitalize on. Aside from spoofing the target brand on the phishing email and website, the chatbot-like component slowly lures the victim to the actual phishing pages. Also, the addition of fake OTP and CAPTCHA pages makes the phishing website makes it seem more legitimate.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
text: Chatbot, OTP, and CAPTCHA technologies are already common and widely used by big brands in their online systems. Therefore, customers are advised to be really careful on what they are clicking online and be aware of sophisticated phishing campaigns such as this.

report_title: SpiderLabs Blog. Interactive Phishing: Using Chatbot-like Web Applications to Harvest Information
